S12_Notes: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1

S1_Notes: 'Effective Friday, March 20th, all schools will be closed for 14 days which will lead right into the Easter break.' Retrieved from: /web/20200414080113/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1024-belize-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19
S2_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19: 'Social gatherings will now be limited to 25 people. This includes wakes, funerals, weddings, and other social events. This limit does not apply to places of employment that should have business protocols for social distancing and business continuity plans in place.

Preventing the virus from entering Belize and practicing self-isolation are the two most important steps that can be taken to avoid community outbreak. The Government stresses the importance of respecting and abiding by the self-isolation instructions issued by the Ministry of Health.
These restrictions will all be reviewed after 30 days'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19

New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19 :'Effective 11:59 p.m. on Saturday, March 21st, the Northern Border of Belize, which includes the Corozal Free Zone, will be closed for traveling but will remain open for cargo transportation. This means that only Belizean nationals, residents, and diplomats residing in Belize will be allowed entry into Belize subject to inspection and possible quarantine for 14 days. Similarly, the Northern Border will be closed for nationals and residents wishing to travel outside of Belize except for emergencies'.

S7_Notes:
'COVID-19 - Alert Regarding Border Closures. Belmopan. March 22, 2020.  The Government of Belize reminds the public that Belize’s borders are closed for entry. Belizeans are being strongly advised against leaving the country, unless it is a case of bona fide emergency. This is being advised for the safety of all.

What do border closures mean? Belizeans, please stay in Belize.
Kindly take note of the border closures below: 
Travellers: Belizeans, diplomats residing in Belize, and foreigners with legal residency in Belize are allowed to enter. Please be aware that those seeking entry to Belize may be subject to a period of 14 days in quarantine to prevent the possible transmission of COVID-19. Guatemalan nationals can depart from Belize to return to their home country'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081225/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1027--covid-19-alert-regarding-border-closures

S1_Notes: 'Effective Friday, March 20th, all schools will be closed for 14 days which will lead right into the Easter break.' Retrieved from: /web/20200414080113/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1024-belize-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19
S2_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19: 'Social gatherings will now be limited to 25 people. This includes wakes, funerals, weddings, and other social events. This limit does not apply to places of employment that should have business protocols for social distancing and business continuity plans in place.

Preventing the virus from entering Belize and practicing self-isolation are the two most important steps that can be taken to avoid community outbreak. The Government stresses the importance of respecting and abiding by the self-isolation instructions issued by the Ministry of Health.
These restrictions will all be reviewed after 30 days'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19

S6_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19 :'Effective 11:59 p.m. on Saturday, March 21st, the Northern Border of Belize, which includes the Corozal Free Zone, will be closed for traveling but will remain open for cargo transportation. This means that only Belizean nationals, residents, and diplomats residing in Belize will be allowed entry into Belize subject to inspection and possible quarantine for 14 days. Similarly, the Northern Border will be closed for nationals and residents wishing to travel outside of Belize except for emergencies'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19
S7_Notes:
'COVID-19 - Alert Regarding Border Closures. Belmopan. March 22, 2020.  The Government of Belize reminds the public that Belize’s borders are closed for entry. Belizeans are being strongly advised against leaving the country, unless it is a case of bona fide emergency. This is being advised for the safety of all.

What do border closures mean? Belizeans, please stay in Belize.
Kindly take note of the border closures below: 
Travellers: Belizeans, diplomats residing in Belize, and foreigners with legal residency in Belize are allowed to enter. Please be aware that those seeking entry to Belize may be subject to a period of 14 days in quarantine to prevent the possible transmission of COVID-19. Guatemalan nationals can depart from Belize to return to their home country'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081225/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1027--covid-19-alert-regarding-border-closures
S12_Notes: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1

S1_Notes: 'Effective Friday, March 20th, all schools will be closed for 14 days which will lead right into the Easter break.' Retrieved from: /web/20200414080113/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1024-belize-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19
S2_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19: 'Social gatherings will now be limited to 25 people. This includes wakes, funerals, weddings, and other social events. This limit does not apply to places of employment that should have business protocols for social distancing and business continuity plans in place.

Preventing the virus from entering Belize and practicing self-isolation are the two most important steps that can be taken to avoid community outbreak. The Government stresses the importance of respecting and abiding by the self-isolation instructions issued by the Ministry of Health.
These restrictions will all be reviewed after 30 days'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19

These restrictions will all be reviewed after 30 days'.

'The public is advised that the Central Medical Laboratory in Belize City is the only laboratory certified to test for COVID-19. Therefore, the public is urged to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19 cases. The Ministry will continue to provide accurate information to the public in a timely fashion'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081741/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-
S6_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19 :'Effective 11:59 p.m. on Saturday, March 21st, the Northern Border of Belize, which includes the Corozal Free Zone, will be closed for traveling but will remain open for cargo transportation. This means that only Belizean nationals, residents, and diplomats residing in Belize will be allowed entry into Belize subject to inspection and possible quarantine for 14 days. Similarly, the Northern Border will be closed for nationals and residents wishing to travel outside of Belize except for emergencies'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19
S7_Notes:
'COVID-19 - Alert Regarding Border Closures. Belmopan. March 22, 2020.  The Government of Belize reminds the public that Belize’s borders are closed for entry. Belizeans are being strongly advised against leaving the country, unless it is a case of bona fide emergency. This is being advised for the safety of all.

What do border closures mean? Belizeans, please stay in Belize.
Kindly take note of the border closures below: 
Travellers: Belizeans, diplomats residing in Belize, and foreigners with legal residency in Belize are allowed to enter. Please be aware that those seeking entry to Belize may be subject to a period of 14 days in quarantine to prevent the possible transmission of COVID-19. Guatemalan nationals can depart from Belize to return to their home country'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081225/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1027--covid-19-alert-regarding-border-closures
S12_Notes: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1

Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19: 'Social gatherings will now be limited to 25 people. This includes wakes, funerals, weddings, and other social events. This limit does not apply to places of employment that should have business protocols for social distancing and business continuity plans in place.

Preventing the virus from entering Belize and practicing self-isolation are the two most important steps that can be taken to avoid community outbreak. The Government stresses the importance of respecting and abiding by the self-isolation instructions issued by the Ministry of Health.
These restrictions will all be reviewed after 30 days'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19
S3_Notes:

S4_Notes: https://lovefm.com/ministry-of-transport-creates-new-bus-schedule/
S5_Notes:
'The public is advised that the Central Medical Laboratory in Belize City is the only laboratory certified to test for COVID-19. Therefore, the public is urged to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19 cases. The Ministry will continue to provide accurate information to the public in a timely fashion'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081741/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-
S6_Notes:
Mar 20, 2020. New Measures Announced to Protect Against COVID-19 :'Effective 11:59 p.m. on Saturday, March 21st, the Northern Border of Belize, which includes the Corozal Free Zone, will be closed for traveling but will remain open for cargo transportation. This means that only Belizean nationals, residents, and diplomats residing in Belize will be allowed entry into Belize subject to inspection and possible quarantine for 14 days. Similarly, the Northern Border will be closed for nationals and residents wishing to travel outside of Belize except for emergencies'.
Retrieved from:https://web.archive.org/web/20200402164847/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1025-new-measures-announced-to-protect-against-covid-19
S7_Notes:
'COVID-19 - Alert Regarding Border Closures. Belmopan. March 22, 2020.  The Government of Belize reminds the public that Belize’s borders are closed for entry. Belizeans are being strongly advised against leaving the country, unless it is a case of bona fide emergency. This is being advised for the safety of all.

What do border closures mean? Belizeans, please stay in Belize.
Kindly take note of the border closures below: 
Travellers: Belizeans, diplomats residing in Belize, and foreigners with legal residency in Belize are allowed to enter. Please be aware that those seeking entry to Belize may be subject to a period of 14 days in quarantine to prevent the possible transmission of COVID-19. Guatemalan nationals can depart from Belize to return to their home country'.
Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414081225/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1027--covid-19-alert-regarding-border-closures
S12_Notes: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1

S9_Notes:
[Original flag: 3.75% - But: Bermuda has no central bank and does not set interest rates centrally. Hence HSBC and Butterfield have differing interest rates.]

IR is 4.75%, set by gov but run through finanicial institution intermediaries. Has not changed through crisis. Bermuda seems to only intermittently sell bond packages.
source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/us-620-million-475-senior-unsecured-notes-due-2029

S12_Notes: 'The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff. Any situation posing a risk to the safety of the general public will be communicated through official Ministry of Health channels.' S8_Notes:
COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. 
Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan
S12_Notes: 'The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff. S2_Notes:
Excerpt from Premier Burt's speech on the 18th of March, 7pm with regard to government action in Bermuda from 19 March onwards: 
'The following Legal Affairs departments: National Drug Control and Child and Family Services, residential treatment services will remain in operation. All other departments in the Department of Legal Affairs will have reduced operations.
The public bus and ferry services are suspended until April 6. Government workers who are not directly involved with the COVID-19 management and operation will work from home until April 6th. Managers will provide guidance to all Public Officers throughout the course of the day tomorrow.
Private businesses are encouraged to ask their employees to work from home, if possible. Otherwise work schedules should be staggered to minimize the number of people in the workplace. Bars, restaurants, and other social establishments are strongly urged to scale down their operations from tonight and enforce social distancing. Essential retail outlets will continue to operate, such as food and medicines and there will be specific guidance issued to all retail establishments tomorrow following the COVID-19 EMO meeting.'
Sources: https://www.gov.bm/articles/premier-david-burt-statement-covid-19 & https://www.gov.bm/articles/emo-statement-19-march-2020

S7_Notes:
Self-quarantine required for arriving passengers from 17 March 2020
Archived Source: /web/20200402174207/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-news?page=4
S8_Notes:
COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. 
Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan

S12_Notes: 'The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff. Any situation posing a risk to the safety of the general public will be communicated through official Ministry of Health channels.' Archived Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402184005/https://www.gov.bm/articles/coronavirus-update-ministry-health-0

S1_Notes:
-'Under the Notice, the Minister of Health, the Hon. Kim Wilson JP, MP, has Ordered the following establishments closed effective March 21, 2020. For public clarity, the establishments are as follows: Schools; Swimming pools in hotels, Airbnb and guest houses; Beauty salons, spas and barbers; Church services (except funerals); Organised sports club activities with more than 50 people; and Concerts with more than 50 people'.
https://www.gov.bm/articles/closure-notice-enforcement-penalties
S2_Notes:
Government statement: 'The Minister of Health signed an Order on Friday closing all schools, tourist accommodation swimming pools, gyms, beauty salons, spas and barbers; as well church services (except funerals), sports club activities and concerts with more than 50 people.
To further reduce the risk of community spread Cabinet has approved the following further actions with effect from 5pm tomorrow, Monday March 23rd:
The Minister of Health will extend the closure Order to include retail stores, cinemas and bars and restaurants limited to take out service only. 
Enforced social distancing should will now be limited to gatherings of no more than 10 people. 
The Royal Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Police Service will be engaged in operations directly aimed at enforcing required quarantine of persons who arrived in Bermuda since 17th March. 
Essential businesses only will be permitted to open and will be required to adopt the aggressive social distancing guidance now in place and on reduced hours. These businesses are banks, food suppliers or supermarkets, pharmacies and gas stations.'

Source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-22-march-2020 & https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-23-march-2020
S3_Notes: Government has called on the public to suspend public gatherings of 50 people or more. Archived Source: /web/20200402175050/https://www.gov.bm/articles/premiers-national-address-covid-19-update
S4_Notes:
'Public Transportation: Recognizing that public transportation has been suspended for now and that we have a number of health professionals who use public transportation, the Department of Public Transportation will put on a special pick up service for our key health workers such as nurses, health technicians and care givers'.
https://www.gov.bm/articles/premier-david-burt-covid-19-update-20-march-2020

Government statement: 'The Minister of Health signed an Order on Friday closing all schools, tourist accommodation swimming pools, gyms, beauty salons, spas and barbers; as well church services (except funerals), sports club activities and concerts with more than 50 people. To further reduce the risk of community spread Cabinet has approved the following further actions with effect from 5pm tomorrow, Monday March 23rd: The Minister of Health will extend the closure Order to include retail stores, cinemas and bars and restaurants limited to take out service only. Enforced social distancing should will now be limited to gatherings of no more than 10 people. The Royal Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Police Service will be engaged in operations directly aimed at enforcing required quarantine of persons who arrived in Bermuda since 17th March. Essential businesses only will be permitted to open and will be required to adopt the aggressive social distancing guidance now in place and on reduced hours. These businesses are banks, food suppliers or supermarkets, pharmacies and gas stations.' Source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-22-march-2020 & https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-23-march-2020
Archived Source: /web/20200402181307/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-23-march-2020

S8_Notes:
COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. 
Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan

S12_Notes: 'The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff. Any situation posing a risk to the safety of the general public will be communicated through official Ministry of Health channels.' The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'.

S1_Notes:
Government statement: 'The Minister of Health signed an Order on Friday closing all schools, tourist accommodation swimming pools, gyms, beauty salons, spas and barbers; as well church services (except funerals), sports club activities and concerts with more than 50 people. To further reduce the risk of community spread Cabinet has approved the following further actions with effect from 5pm tomorrow, Monday March 23rd: The Minister of Health will extend the closure Order to include retail stores, cinemas and bars and restaurants limited to take out service only. Enforced social distancing should will now be limited to gatherings of no more than 10 people. The Royal Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Police Service will be engaged in operations directly aimed at enforcing required quarantine of persons who arrived in Bermuda since 17th March. Essential businesses only will be permitted to open and will be required to adopt the aggressive social distancing guidance now in place and on reduced hours. These businesses are banks, food suppliers or supermarkets, pharmacies and gas stations.' Source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-22-march-2020 &

'The Ministry of Finance is working closely with the Department of Workforce Development and local banks to ensure that the funds are available for unemployment benefits. Government is utilising Section 10B of the Public Treasury (Administration and Payments) Act 1969 which established the Unemployment Insurance Fund in 2002. This legislation provides the authority for the Minister of Finance to make payments out of the Unemployment Insurance Fund for the purpose of assisting unemployed persons.'

S1_Notes:
Government statement: 'The Minister of Health signed an Order on Friday closing all schools, tourist accommodation swimming pools, gyms, beauty salons, spas and barbers; as well church services (except funerals), sports club activities and concerts with more than 50 people. To further reduce the risk of community spread Cabinet has approved the following further actions with effect from 5pm tomorrow, Monday March 23rd: The Minister of Health will extend the closure Order to include retail stores, cinemas and bars and restaurants limited to take out service only. Enforced social distancing should will now be limited to gatherings of no more than 10 people. The Royal Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Police Service will be engaged in operations directly aimed at enforcing required quarantine of persons who arrived in Bermuda since 17th March. Essential businesses only will be permitted to open and will be required to adopt the aggressive social distancing guidance now in place and on reduced hours. These businesses are banks, food suppliers or supermarkets, pharmacies and gas stations.' Source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-22-march-2020 &
Archived Source: /web/20200402181307/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-23-march-2020
S2_Notes: The Premier of Bermuda gave a national address stating that from 4 April at 6am, Bermuda will implement the Shelter in Place measure for 14 days. The Shelter in Place is scheduled to end on 18 April. Archived Source: /web/20200402180713/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-premier-david-burt

S7_Notes:
'The current restriction on commercial aircraft operations is in place for two weeks from 21 March, which takes us to 4 April. However, commercial airlines have generally suspended service to Bermuda for the month of April. The Cabinet will discuss the future status of resuming scheduled commercial airline traffic'. 
https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-health-update-30-march-2020
S8_Notes: COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan
S9_Notes:
COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan

'The Ministry of Finance is working closely with the Department of Workforce Development and local banks to ensure that the funds are available for unemployment benefits. Government is utilising Section 10B of the Public Treasury (Administration and Payments) Act 1969 which established the Unemployment Insurance Fund in 2002. This legislation provides the authority for the Minister of Finance to make payments out of the Unemployment Insurance Fund for the purpose of assisting unemployed persons.'
Archived Source: /web/20200410025147/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministry-shares-phone-numbers-assist-unemployment-benefit-application-processing
S12_Notes:
'Surveillance for respiratory illness has been enhanced in collaboration with local public health partners. Persons with respiratory illness including fever and cough should call ahead and inform their health care provider of their travel history prior to attending for medical care.'

To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan

'The Ministry of Finance is working closely with the Department of Workforce Development and local banks to ensure that the funds are available for unemployment benefits. Government is utilising Section 10B of the Public Treasury (Administration and Payments) Act 1969 which established the Unemployment Insurance Fund in 2002. This legislation provides the authority for the Minister of Finance to make payments out of the Unemployment Insurance Fund for the purpose of assisting unemployed persons.'
Archived Source: /web/20200410025147/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministry-shares-phone-numbers-assist-unemployment-benefit-application-processing

Archived Source: /web/20200410025613/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus

To further reduce the risk of community spread Cabinet has approved the following further actions with effect from 5pm tomorrow, Monday March 23rd: The Minister of Health will extend the closure Order to include retail stores, cinemas and bars and restaurants limited to take out service only. Enforced social distancing should will now be limited to gatherings of no more than 10 people. The Royal Bermuda Regiment and the Bermuda Police Service will be engaged in operations directly aimed at enforcing required quarantine of persons who arrived in Bermuda since 17th March. Essential businesses only will be permitted to open and will be required to adopt the aggressive social distancing guidance now in place and on reduced hours. These businesses are banks, food suppliers or supermarkets, pharmacies and gas stations.' Source: https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-update-22-march-2020 &

S8_Notes: COVID19- FISCAL PLAN. The current actions being taken as part of the Ministry of Finance COVID-19 - Fiscal Plan are as follows: -To provide financing to supplement reduced revenues, the Ministry is taking the necessary action to secure emergency liquidity lines of credit with local financial institutions. The required discussions have been held with all relevant parties, to gain the necessary approvals, including an associated $150 million increase in the debt ceiling. These facilities will be used only when it is absolutely necessary. The Ministry will provide additional funding for the Department of Financial Assistance to further assist Bermuda’s unemployed. -Lower priority expenditures will be curtailed to ensure that spending needed for COVID-19 matters can be maintained. To that end, over the next 3 months Government will: -Delay the start of any capital projects that have not commenced; Institute an immediate freeze on posts that are not required to address COVID 19 or to protect Bermuda’s national interests; -Continue the ban on non-essential government travel; and -Reduce all discretionary spending, including training, materials and supplies, clothing and uniforms etc'. Archived Source: /web/20200402182725/https://www.gov.bm/articles/covid-19-fiscal-plan

S8_Notes:
The Federal government announces a total of R$ 169,6 billion over three months to tackle the effects of Covid-19. This includes up to R$ 98,4 billion to the most vulnerable people, R$ 59,4 billion to protect jobs, and R$ 11,8 billion to fight the pandemic.

Obs. As this includes R$ 4,5 billion to healthcare, I will add only R$ 165,1 billion here.

Link: http://www.economia.gov.br/noticias/2020/marco/equipe-economica-reforca-em-mais-r-22-bilhoes-plano-de-combate-aos-efeitos-do-coronavirus and http://www.economia.gov.br/noticias/2020/marco/governo-anuncia-medidas-para-proteger-empregos-e-distribuir-renda

https://www12.senado.leg.br/noticias/materias/2020/04/16/decisao-do-stf-sobre-isolamento-de-estados-e-municipios-repercute-no-senado
Even though the Presidency in Brazil is recommending states and cities to re-open stores and other economic activities, the Supreme Court of Brazil decided states and cities have the autonomy concerning the measures against COVID-19 in their respective territory.
Some states, like Rio de Janeiro and Distrito Federal required the re-opening of stores and other services. Other states and cities, like Paraíba, Acre, Amapá and Salavdor, however, are keeping isolation measure for more 15 days, as indicated in the links above.
In some states the use of mask in public will be required.

https://www12.senado.leg.br/noticias/materias/2020/04/16/decisao-do-stf-sobre-isolamento-de-estados-e-municipios-repercute-no-senado
Even though the Presidency in Brazil is recommending states and cities to re-open stores and other economic activities, the Supreme Court of Brazil decided states and cities have the autonomy concerning the measures against COVID-19 in their respective territory.
Some states, like Rio de Janeiro and Distrito Federal required the re-opening of stores and other services. Other states and cities, like Paraíba, Acre, Amapá and Salavdor, however, are keeping isolation measure for more 15 days, as indicated in the links above.
In some states the use of mask in public will be required.

S12_Notes:
'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/

S12_Notes:
'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/

'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/

S3_Notes:
Gatherings with more than 100 people need to be cancelled, referring to stage 1 of the Covid-19 Preparedness Plan of Barbados
Archived Source: /web/20200402223403/https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244445/covid-19-management-response-plans-stage
S4_Notes:
'In light of Barbados recording its first two cases of COVID-19, Chief Executive Officer of the Transport Board, Fabian Wharton, is assuring the public that his organization is taking every possible measure to ensure the safety of commuters.

Speaking from the Weymouth headquarters, Mr. Wharton said: “We have been monitoring the situation across the region very closely and we are being very proactive in our approach to preparing for the inevitability of the virus.  Precautionary measures have been taken and we have been educating the staff, particularly drivers, as it relates to good hygiene practices.”
Archived Source: /web/20200402224248/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/transport-board-ensuring-safety-of-commuters/

S10_Notes:
'Government has ordered the Barbados Drug Service (BDS) to stockpile a six-month supply of pharmaceuticals in preparation for any fall-out that might occur as a result of the COVID-19 global pandemic.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225334/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/government-stockpiling-pharmaceuticals/
S12_Notes:
'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/

S4_Notes:
'In light of Barbados recording its first two cases of COVID-19, Chief Executive Officer of the Transport Board, Fabian Wharton, is assuring the public that his organization is taking every possible measure to ensure the safety of commuters.

Speaking from the Weymouth headquarters, Mr. Wharton said: “We have been monitoring the situation across the region very closely and we are being very proactive in our approach to preparing for the inevitability of the virus.  Precautionary measures have been taken and we have been educating the staff, particularly drivers, as it relates to good hygiene practices.”
Archived Source: /web/20200402224248/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/transport-board-ensuring-safety-of-commuters/

S9_Notes: “And, therefore, Government has taken the firm decision that we will undertake countercyclical fiscal policies in order to make sure that if a man or woman cannot work fully within the tourism sector, that there will be other areas of economic activity in the country that we will now trigger or expedite, in order to keep as many people working as possible,” she explained. She revealed that Dr. Greenidge had been in contact with the International Monetary Fund to discuss “a little elbow room” for this country under the Barbados Economic Recovery and Transformation (BERT) Programme. S1_Notes:
'The Ministry of Education has therefore suspended with immediate effect the conduct of all CXC on-site and centre moderation exercises and CXC SBA practicals in Physical Education, Theatre Arts and Music. These suspensions will remain in effect until further advice is received from the Ministry of Health and Wellness regarding the COVID-19 national status. Kindly note that provision has been made for the appropriate rescheduling in due course.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402220748/https://mes.gov.bb/News/Latest/Update-on-COVID-19.aspx

S9_Notes: “And, therefore, Government has taken the firm decision that we will undertake countercyclical fiscal policies in order to make sure that if a man or woman cannot work fully within the tourism sector, that there will be other areas of economic activity in the country that we will now trigger or expedite, in order to keep as many people working as possible,” she explained. She revealed that Dr. Greenidge had been in contact with the International Monetary Fund to discuss “a little elbow room” for this country under the Barbados Economic Recovery and Transformation (BERT) Programme. S10_Notes:
'Government has ordered the Barbados Drug Service (BDS) to stockpile a six-month supply of pharmaceuticals in preparation for any fall-out that might occur as a result of the COVID-19 global pandemic.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225334/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/government-stockpiling-pharmaceuticals/
S12_Notes:
'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/
S13_Notes:
'The Ministry has initiated the process of contact tracing to identify every individual who came in close contact with all cases and will quarantine such persons for 14 days. They will also be tested for COVID-19 if they become symptomatic.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402230214/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/two-new-covid-19-cases-in-barbados/

S1_Notes:
'The Ministry of Education has therefore suspended with immediate effect the conduct of all CXC on-site and centre moderation exercises and CXC SBA practicals in Physical Education, Theatre Arts and Music. These suspensions will remain in effect until further advice is received from the Ministry of Health and Wellness regarding the COVID-19 national status. Kindly note that provision has been made for the appropriate rescheduling in due course.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402220748/https://mes.gov.bb/News/Latest/Update-on-COVID-19.aspx
S3_Notes:

S4_Notes:
'In light of Barbados recording its first two cases of COVID-19, Chief Executive Officer of the Transport Board, Fabian Wharton, is assuring the public that his organization is taking every possible measure to ensure the safety of commuters.

Speaking from the Weymouth headquarters, Mr. Wharton said: “We have been monitoring the situation across the region very closely and we are being very proactive in our approach to preparing for the inevitability of the virus.  Precautionary measures have been taken and we have been educating the staff, particularly drivers, as it relates to good hygiene practices.”
Archived Source: /web/20200402224248/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/transport-board-ensuring-safety-of-commuters/

S2_Notes:
'Stage 3 of the COVID-19 National Preparedness Plan
A public health emergency has been declared
A curfew from Saturday, March 28, to Tuesday, April 14, 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. This may be extended.
Persons are confined to their places of residence during curfew hours
Limited movement during the day
Continue to practise physical distancing of six feet between persons
The plan is being implemented in a phased manner based on the intensity of spread.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402224853/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020-fbclidiwar32cxrvq5zqfy0msm6nybss1_90a-nygoo3isvesndcghk-wagaik1dz48/

S8_Notes:
“And, therefore, Government has taken the firm decision that we will undertake countercyclical fiscal policies in order to make sure that if a man or woman cannot work fully within the tourism sector, that there will be other areas of economic activity in the country that we will now trigger or expedite, in order to keep as many people working as possible,” she explained.

She revealed that Dr. Greenidge had been in contact with the International Monetary Fund to discuss “a little elbow room” for this country under the Barbados Economic Recovery and Transformation (BERT) Programme.

S9_Notes: “And, therefore, Government has taken the firm decision that we will undertake countercyclical fiscal policies in order to make sure that if a man or woman cannot work fully within the tourism sector, that there will be other areas of economic activity in the country that we will now trigger or expedite, in order to keep as many people working as possible,” she explained. She revealed that Dr. Greenidge had been in contact with the International Monetary Fund to discuss “a little elbow room” for this country under the Barbados Economic Recovery and Transformation (BERT) Programme. Archived Source: /web/20200402225334/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/government-stockpiling-pharmaceuticals/
S12_Notes:
'Since January 26, 162 people arriving in Barbados from affected areas have been placed in home quarantine for a period of 14 days. Today, there are 42 people in quarantine. No-one exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 – cough, fever or breathlessness – is placed in quarantine, and if these symptoms occur while in quarantine, the person will be isolated and tested. Anyone arriving in Barbados exhibiting symptoms will be placed in isolation immediately. All the tests conducted at the Best-dos Santos Public Health Laboratory so far have been negative.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402225720/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/no-confirmed-cases-of-covid-19-in-barbados/
S13_Notes:
'The Ministry has initiated the process of contact tracing to identify every individual who came in close contact with all cases and will quarantine such persons for 14 days. They will also be tested for COVID-19 if they become symptomatic.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402230214/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/two-new-covid-19-cases-in-barbados/

'In light of Barbados recording its first two cases of COVID-19, Chief Executive Officer of the Transport Board, Fabian Wharton, is assuring the public that his organization is taking every possible measure to ensure the safety of commuters.

Speaking from the Weymouth headquarters, Mr. Wharton said: “We have been monitoring the situation across the region very closely and we are being very proactive in our approach to preparing for the inevitability of the virus.  Precautionary measures have been taken and we have been educating the staff, particularly drivers, as it relates to good hygiene practices.”

S9_Notes: From 7 to 2% for Commercial Banks. 'The Central Bank of Barbados (CBB) announced a series of measures (effective April 1, 2020) to help support commercial banks and other deposit-taking institution manage the economic fallout from the coronavirus shock. Specifically: i) the Bank’s discount rate at which it provides overnight lending to banks and deposit-taking non-banks licensed under the Financial Institutions Act was reduced from 7 percent to 2 percent; ii) the securities ratio for banks was lowered from 17.5 percent to 5 percent; iii) the 1.5 percent securities ratio for non-bank deposit taking licensees was eliminated; and, iv) the Bank indicated it stands ready to make collateralized loans for up to six months as liquidity support for licensees.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

S3_Notes: Entertainment events and large gatherings with more than 100 people are to be postponed for the next three months as a precautionary measure against the potential spread of the COVID-19 virus. Prime Minister Mia Mottley made the announcement on Monday night (16.03) as she updated the nation on the island's preparedness plan for the novel COVID-19. Source: https://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/no-large-gatherings-next-three-months
S4_Notes: 'There has been no decision made in relation to when bus services at the Transport Board will be halted. This statement came in light of the ongoing 24-hour Covid-19 curfew placed on the country. Chief Executive Officer, Fabian Wharton says the board will allow bus services to continue for now.' Source: https://www.cbc.bb/2020/04/07/transport-board-services-continue/
S5_Notes: Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Additionaly, information is being posted on the Government Information Service website with a special web page dedicated to Covid-19. Source: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020
S6_Notes:
“Acting Prime Minister Sanita Bradshaw announced that a 24-hour curfew will come into effect at 17:00 (local time) on Friday, April 3, in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak on Barbados.” Source: https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/328801/barbados-authorities-announce-24-hour-curfew-from-april-3-update-1

“A daily curfew operates from 8pm to 6am local. In addition, a 24 hour curfew will be imposed starting on Friday 3 April at 8pm.” Source: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/barbados/coronavirus
S7_Notes: A mandatory 14-day quarantine in a Government facility for all persons entering Barbados. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
S8_Notes: 'The Government of Barbados (GoB) has identified upfront emergency health and capital expenditures needed to manage and mitigate the spread of infection. This includes resources to refurbish the hospital and clinics, build isolation centers, and provision critical medications and supplies.' Source: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S9_Notes: From 7 to 2% for Commercial Banks. 'The Central Bank of Barbados (CBB) announced a series of measures (effective April 1, 2020) to help support commercial banks and other deposit-taking institution manage the economic fallout from the coronavirus shock. Specifically: i) the Bank’s discount rate at which it provides overnight lending to banks and deposit-taking non-banks licensed under the Financial Institutions Act was reduced from 7 percent to 2 percent; ii) the securities ratio for banks was lowered from 17.5 percent to 5 percent; iii) the 1.5 percent securities ratio for non-bank deposit taking licensees was eliminated; and, iv) the Bank indicated it stands ready to make collateralized loans for up to six months as liquidity support for licensees.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S10_Notes: 'On Friday, a 40-foot container from China arrived at the Bridgetown Port with 4500 goggles and over 16,000 face masks. The QEH Chair disclosed that another shipment from the Asian country could arrive by the middle of this week. 'We have another container due in on Wednesday with more surgical masks and gowns. So what we have been doing, not only in the case of ventilators, is ensuring that we have a steady supply.'' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/barbados-looking-to-other-suppliers-for-equipment/
S12_Notes: 'Mass testing of persons for the COVID-19 virus is a luxury that this country cannot afford at this time. COVID-19 Czar, Richard Carter, says this is because of the limitations on the availability of the items required for testing, including swabs and test kits. He was speaking yesterday on one of the local radio call-in programmes as he responded to a caller who suggested that everyone should be tested. Carter, reflecting on the finite supplies, indicated that they are limiting the testing to ensure that the resources currently at their disposal are used in instances where they are absolutely necessary. 'Mass testing of the whole population is not an option that we can use at this moment and it is perhaps not an indication of where we are in the course of the epidemic,' he stated.' Source: https://www.barbadosadvocate.com/news/no-mass-testing-right-now
S13_Notes: 'Acting Chief Medical Officer Dr Anton Best said there is no evidence yet of community spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) but health officials are aggressively using contact tracing to limit an increase in infections.' Source: https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244799/-aggressive-contact-tracing-continues

S5_Notes: Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Additionaly, information is being posted on the Government Information Service website with a special web page dedicated to Covid-19. Source: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020
S6_Notes:
“Acting Prime Minister Sanita Bradshaw announced that a 24-hour curfew will come into effect at 17:00 (local time) on Friday, April 3, in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak on Barbados.” Source: https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/328801/barbados-authorities-announce-24-hour-curfew-from-april-3-update-1

“A daily curfew operates from 8pm to 6am local. In addition, a 24 hour curfew will be imposed starting on Friday 3 April at 8pm.” Source: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/barbados/coronavirus
S7_Notes: A mandatory 14-day quarantine in a Government facility for all persons entering Barbados. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
S8_Notes: 'The Government of Barbados (GoB) has identified upfront emergency health and capital expenditures needed to manage and mitigate the spread of infection. This includes resources to refurbish the hospital and clinics, build isolation centers, and provision critical medications and supplies.' Source: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S9_Notes: From 7 to 2% for Commercial Banks. 'The Central Bank of Barbados (CBB) announced a series of measures (effective April 1, 2020) to help support commercial banks and other deposit-taking institution manage the economic fallout from the coronavirus shock. Specifically: i) the Bank’s discount rate at which it provides overnight lending to banks and deposit-taking non-banks licensed under the Financial Institutions Act was reduced from 7 percent to 2 percent; ii) the securities ratio for banks was lowered from 17.5 percent to 5 percent; iii) the 1.5 percent securities ratio for non-bank deposit taking licensees was eliminated; and, iv) the Bank indicated it stands ready to make collateralized loans for up to six months as liquidity support for licensees.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S10_Notes: 'On Friday, a 40-foot container from China arrived at the Bridgetown Port with 4500 goggles and over 16,000 face masks. The QEH Chair disclosed that another shipment from the Asian country could arrive by the middle of this week. 'We have another container due in on Wednesday with more surgical masks and gowns. So what we have been doing, not only in the case of ventilators, is ensuring that we have a steady supply.'' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/barbados-looking-to-other-suppliers-for-equipment/
S12_Notes: 'Mass testing of persons for the COVID-19 virus is a luxury that this country cannot afford at this time. COVID-19 Czar, Richard Carter, says this is because of the limitations on the availability of the items required for testing, including swabs and test kits. He was speaking yesterday on one of the local radio call-in programmes as he responded to a caller who suggested that everyone should be tested. Carter, reflecting on the finite supplies, indicated that they are limiting the testing to ensure that the resources currently at their disposal are used in instances where they are absolutely necessary. 'Mass testing of the whole population is not an option that we can use at this moment and it is perhaps not an indication of where we are in the course of the epidemic,' he stated.' Source: https://www.barbadosadvocate.com/news/no-mass-testing-right-now
S13_Notes: 'Acting Chief Medical Officer Dr Anton Best said there is no evidence yet of community spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) but health officials are aggressively using contact tracing to limit an increase in infections.' Source: https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244799/-aggressive-contact-tracing-continues

S1_Notes:
'The Ministry of Education has therefore suspended with immediate effect the conduct of all CXC on-site and centre moderation exercises and CXC SBA practicals in Physical Education, Theatre Arts and Music. These suspensions will remain in effect until further advice is received from the Ministry of Health and Wellness regarding the COVID-19 national status. Kindly note that provision has been made for the appropriate rescheduling in due course.'

'Stage 3 of the COVID-19 National Preparedness Plan
A public health emergency has been declared
A curfew from Saturday, March 28, to Tuesday, April 14, 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. This may be extended.
Persons are confined to their places of residence during curfew hours
Limited movement during the day
Continue to practise physical distancing of six feet between persons
The plan is being implemented in a phased manner based on the intensity of spread.'

S4_Notes: 'The Transport Board reversed its decision to end regular scheduled services come Thursday (09.04),  the deadline for senior citizens to collect their pensions from post offices around the island. Wharton said: 'We decided to keep the service going because there are people that will still rely on public transport to meet their day-to-day needs. We are concerned about people joyriding, using our service for non-essential travel, and we would ask the public to desist from doing that. We have made the decision to keep the bus service open for now. We will inform the public of any further changes when necessary.' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/transport-board-no-longer-suspending-services/

S3_Notes:
Entertainment events and large gatherings with more than 100 people are to be postponed for the next three months as a precautionary measure against the potential spread of the COVID-19 virus. Prime Minister Mia Mottley made the announcement on Monday night (16.03) as she updated the nation on the island's preparedness plan for the novel Covid-19.

Source: https://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/no-large-gatherings-next-three-months
S4_Notes: 'The Transport Board reversed its decision to end regular scheduled services come Thursday (09.04),  the deadline for senior citizens to collect their pensions from post offices around the island. Wharton said: 'We decided to keep the service going because there are people that will still rely on public transport to meet their day-to-day needs. We are concerned about people joyriding, using our service for non-essential travel, and we would ask the public to desist from doing that. We have made the decision to keep the bus service open for now. We will inform the public of any further changes when necessary.' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/transport-board-no-longer-suspending-services/
S5_Notes: Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Additionaly, information is being posted on the Government Information Service website with a special web page dedicated to Covid-19. Source: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020
S6_Notes: “Acting Prime Minister Sanita Bradshaw announced that a 24-hour curfew will come into effect at 17:00 (local time) on Friday, April 3, in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak on Barbados.” Source: https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/328801/barbados-authorities-announce-24-hour-curfew-from-april-3-update-1 “A daily curfew operates from 8pm to 6am local. In addition, a 24 hour curfew will be imposed starting on Friday 3 April at 8pm.” Source: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/barbados/coronavirus
S7_Notes: A mandatory 14-day quarantine in a Government facility for all persons entering Barbados. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
S8_Notes: 'The Government of Barbados (GoB) has identified upfront emergency health and capital expenditures needed to manage and mitigate the spread of infection. This includes resources to refurbish the hospital and clinics, build isolation centers, and provision critical medications and supplies.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S9_Notes: From 7 to 2% for Commercial Banks. 'The Central Bank of Barbados (CBB) announced a series of measures (effective April 1, 2020) to help support commercial banks and other deposit-taking institution manage the economic fallout from the coronavirus shock. Specifically: i) the Bank’s discount rate at which it provides overnight lending to banks and deposit-taking non-banks licensed under the Financial Institutions Act was reduced from 7 percent to 2 percent; ii) the securities ratio for banks was lowered from 17.5 percent to 5 percent; iii) the 1.5 percent securities ratio for non-bank deposit taking licensees was eliminated; and, iv) the Bank indicated it stands ready to make collateralized loans for up to six months as liquidity support for licensees.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S10_Notes: 'On Friday, a 40-foot container from China arrived at the Bridgetown Port with 4500 goggles and over 16,000 face masks. The QEH Chair disclosed that another shipment from the Asian country could arrive by the middle of this week. 'We have another container due in on Wednesday with more surgical masks and gowns. So what we have been doing, not only in the case of ventilators, is ensuring that we have a steady supply.'' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/barbados-looking-to-other-suppliers-for-equipment/
S12_Notes: 'Mass testing of persons for the COVID-19 virus is a luxury that this country cannot afford at this time. COVID-19 Czar, Richard Carter, says this is because of the limitations on the availability of the items required for testing, including swabs and test kits. He was speaking yesterday on one of the local radio call-in programmes as he responded to a caller who suggested that everyone should be tested. Carter, reflecting on the finite supplies, indicated that they are limiting the testing to ensure that the resources currently at their disposal are used in instances where they are absolutely necessary. 'Mass testing of the whole population is not an option that we can use at this moment and it is perhaps not an indication of where we are in the course of the epidemic,' he stated.' Source: https://www.barbadosadvocate.com/news/no-mass-testing-right-now
S13_Notes: 'Acting Chief Medical Officer Dr Anton Best said there is no evidence yet of community spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) but health officials are aggressively using contact tracing to limit an increase in infections.' Source: https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244799/-aggressive-contact-tracing-continues

S1_Notes:
'The Ministry of Education has therefore suspended with immediate effect the conduct of all CXC on-site and centre moderation exercises and CXC SBA practicals in Physical Education, Theatre Arts and Music. These suspensions will remain in effect until further advice is received from the Ministry of Health and Wellness regarding the COVID-19 national status. Kindly note that provision has been made for the appropriate rescheduling in due course.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402220748/https://mes.gov.bb/News/Latest/Update-on-COVID-19.aspx

'Stage 3 of the COVID-19 National Preparedness Plan
A public health emergency has been declared
A curfew from Saturday, March 28, to Tuesday, April 14, 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. This may be extended.
Persons are confined to their places of residence during curfew hours
Limited movement during the day
Continue to practise physical distancing of six feet between persons
The plan is being implemented in a phased manner based on the intensity of spread.'

Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
S10_Notes: 'On Friday, a 40-foot container from China arrived at the Bridgetown Port with 4500 goggles and over 16,000 face masks. The QEH Chair disclosed that another shipment from the Asian country could arrive by the middle of this week. 'We have another container due in on Wednesday with more surgical masks and gowns. So what we have been doing, not only in the case of ventilators, is ensuring that we have a steady supply.'' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200410020309/https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/barbados-looking-to-other-suppliers-for-equipment/
S12_Notes: 'Mass testing of persons for the COVID-19 virus is a luxury that this country cannot afford at this time. COVID-19 Czar, Richard Carter, says this is because of the limitations on the availability of the items required for testing, including swabs and test kits. He was speaking yesterday on one of the local radio call-in programmes as he responded to a caller who suggested that everyone should be tested. Carter, reflecting on the finite supplies, indicated that they are limiting the testing to ensure that the resources currently at their disposal are used in instances where they are absolutely necessary. 'Mass testing of the whole population is not an option that we can use at this moment and it is perhaps not an indication of where we are in the course of the epidemic,' he stated.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200407025412/https://www.barbadosadvocate.com/news/no-mass-testing-right-now
S13_Notes: 'Acting Chief Medical Officer Dr Anton Best said there is no evidence yet of community spread of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) but health officials are aggressively using contact tracing to limit an increase in infections.' Source: https://www.nationnews.com/nationnews/news/244799/-aggressive-contact-tracing-continues

S1_Notes:
'The Ministry of Education has therefore suspended with immediate effect the conduct of all CXC on-site and centre moderation exercises and CXC SBA practicals in Physical Education, Theatre Arts and Music. These suspensions will remain in effect until further advice is received from the Ministry of Health and Wellness regarding the COVID-19 national status. Kindly note that provision has been made for the appropriate rescheduling in due course.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402220748/https://mes.gov.bb/News/Latest/Update-on-COVID-19.aspx
S2_Notes:
'Stage 3 of the COVID-19 National Preparedness Plan
A public health emergency has been declared
A curfew from Saturday, March 28, to Tuesday, April 14, 8:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. This may be extended.
Persons are confined to their places of residence during curfew hours
Limited movement during the day
Continue to practise physical distancing of six feet between persons
The plan is being implemented in a phased manner based on the intensity of spread.'
Archived Source: /web/20200402224853/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020-fbclidiwar32cxrvq5zqfy0msm6nybss1_90a-nygoo3isvesndcghk-wagaik1dz48/
S3_Notes: Entertainment events and large gatherings with more than 100 people are to be postponed for the next three months as a precautionary measure against the potential spread of the COVID-19 virus. Prime Minister Mia Mottley made the announcement on Monday night (16.03) as she updated the nation on the island's preparedness plan for the novel COVID-19. Source: https://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/no-large-gatherings-next-three-months
S4_Notes: 'The Transport Board reversed its decision to end regular scheduled services come Thursday (09.04),  the deadline for senior citizens to collect their pensions from post offices around the island. Wharton said: 'We decided to keep the service going because there are people that will still rely on public transport to meet their day-to-day needs. We are concerned about people joyriding, using our service for non-essential travel, and we would ask the public to desist from doing that. We have made the decision to keep the bus service open for now. We will inform the public of any further changes when necessary.' Source: https://barbadostoday.bb/2020/04/07/transport-board-no-longer-suspending-services/
S5_Notes: Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Additionaly, information is being posted on the Government Information Service website with a special web page dedicated to Covid-19. Source: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020
S6_Notes: “Acting Prime Minister Sanita Bradshaw announced that a 24-hour curfew will come into effect at 17:00 (local time) on Friday, April 3, in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak on Barbados.” Source: https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/328801/barbados-authorities-announce-24-hour-curfew-from-april-3-update-1 “A daily curfew operates from 8pm to 6am local. In addition, a 24 hour curfew will be imposed starting on Friday 3 April at 8pm.” Source: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/barbados/coronavirus
S7_Notes: A mandatory 14-day quarantine in a Government facility for all persons entering Barbados. Source: https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
S8_Notes: 'The Government of Barbados (GoB) has identified upfront emergency health and capital expenditures needed to manage and mitigate the spread of infection. This includes resources to refurbish the hospital and clinics, build isolation centers, and provision critical medications and supplies.' Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200414010927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

S2_Notes:
There are no direct measures for workplace closure, but some procedure and advice have been established by the Ministry of Health (protocol for when a worker is positive for covid-19 and protocol for disinfection of workplace) 
/web/20200404200230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Procedures%20for%20Workplace%20in%20the%20event%20of%20a%20member%20of%20staff%20is%20diagnosed%20with%20COVID-19.pdf
/web/20200404200352/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Guideline%20for%20Cleaning%20and%20Disinfection%20of%20General%20Workplaces%20%28OHD%20Feb%202020%29.pdf
S4_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has provided advisory for safe use of public facilities, such as public transportation, but other tan recommendations there is no measure closing it.
