S12_Notes:
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

S1_Notes:
On March 10th, Brunei’s Ministry of Education announced that the first school term break scheduled for March 16 would be moved up to March 11. 
/web/20200404181841/http://www.moe.gov.bn/SitePages/NewsArticle.aspx?AID=636

On March 25, the Minister announced classes would be held online, effective since March 30
Official statements at: /web/20200405011037/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
S2_Notes:
There are no direct measures for workplace closure, but some procedure and advice have been established by the Ministry of Health (protocol for when a worker is positive for covid-19 and protocol for disinfection of workplace) 
/web/20200404200230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Procedures%20for%20Workplace%20in%20the%20event%20of%20a%20member%20of%20staff%20is%20diagnosed%20with%20COVID-19.pdf
/web/20200404200352/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Guideline%20for%20Cleaning%20and%20Disinfection%20of%20General%20Workplaces%20%28OHD%20Feb%202020%29.pdf
S3_Notes:
13/03 Ministry of Health informs all mass gatherings, including weddings and sports events are temporarily prohibited.
Source with official media statements: /web/20200404202614/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/3/
From March 17, mosques, suraus and religious halls must be closed (first for a week, then extended for another week on March 23 and for another one on March 30)
From March 18, all cinemas and museums are closed
From March 19, all restaurants are not allowed to have dine-in services; only takeouts
S4_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has provided advisory for safe use of public facilities, such as public transportation, but other tan recommendations there is no measure closing it.
/web/20200404195342/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/ADVISORY%20FOR%20SAFE%20USE%20OF%20PUBLIC%20FACILITIES.pdf
S5_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.
Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx
According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
S6_Notes:
There is no direct policy regarding restrictions to internal movement. Only since March 19 the Ministry of Health released an andvisory for safe use of public facilities in general (supply-sided)
/web/20200404204950/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/ADVISORY%20FOR%20SAFE%20USE%20OF%20PUBLIC%20FACILITIES.pdf

S12_Notes:
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

S1_Notes:
On March 10th, Brunei’s Ministry of Education announced that the first school term break scheduled for March 16 would be moved up to March 11. 
/web/20200404181841/http://www.moe.gov.bn/SitePages/NewsArticle.aspx?AID=636

On March 25, the Minister announced classes would be held online, effective since March 30
Official statements at: /web/20200405011037/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
S2_Notes:
There are no direct measures for workplace closure, but some procedure and advice have been established by the Ministry of Health (protocol for when a worker is positive for covid-19 and protocol for disinfection of workplace) 
/web/20200404200230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Procedures%20for%20Workplace%20in%20the%20event%20of%20a%20member%20of%20staff%20is%20diagnosed%20with%20COVID-19.pdf
/web/20200404200352/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Guideline%20for%20Cleaning%20and%20Disinfection%20of%20General%20Workplaces%20%28OHD%20Feb%202020%29.pdf
S3_Notes:
13/03 Ministry of Health informs all mass gatherings, including weddings and sports events are temporarily prohibited.
Source with official media statements: /web/20200404202614/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/3/
From March 17, mosques, suraus and religious halls must be closed (first for a week, then extended for another week on March 23 and for another one on March 30)
From March 18, all cinemas and museums are closed
From March 19, all restaurants are not allowed to have dine-in services; only takeouts
S4_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has provided advisory for safe use of public facilities, such as public transportation, but other tan recommendations there is no measure closing it.
/web/20200404195342/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/ADVISORY%20FOR%20SAFE%20USE%20OF%20PUBLIC%20FACILITIES.pdf
S5_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.
Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx
According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
S6_Notes:
There is no direct policy regarding restrictions to internal movement. Only since March 19 the Ministry of Health released an andvisory for safe use of public facilities in general (supply-sided)

From March 19, all restaurants are not allowed to have dine-in services; only takeouts

S12_Notes:
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

On March 25, the Minister announced classes would be held online, effective since March 30

S12_Notes:
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

S8_Notes:
Effective from April 1, the Government has proposed a BND 450 million Stimulus Package to mitigate the impact of COVID-19.

This package includes different measures such as:

•	MSME to defer social security contributions (TAP and SCP for employees earning B$1,500 and below (for MSMEs with employees fewer tan 100)
•	Government to finance the SCP contribution of self-employed individuals.
•	30% discount of the rental rates of government buildings for MSMEs in the tourism, hospitalitym restaurants and transportation (air and wáter) sectors.
•	50% tax discount on wáter and electricity bills for MSMEs in the targetted sectors 
•	15% discount on water and electricity bills for MSMEs in the targetted sectors 
•	Assist MSMEs to participate on e-platforms
•	6 month contract extension for I-ready apprentices in the public and private sectors with contracts expiring before September 2020
•	Temporary exemption of custom and excise duties for personal hygiene products
•	25% wage subsidy to local workers in MSMEs with 100 employees and below for 3 months

/web/20200405031922/https://www.mofe.gov.bn/Lists/News/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=108
/web/20200405032027/https://www.mofe.gov.bn/Lists/News/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=101

S12_Notes:
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
Policy is to test anyone that has had contact or has arrived from abroad and developed symptoms

At present, any citizen and permanent resident of Brunei Darussalam or foreigner within the country is eligible for the COVID-19 testing (free of charge) if they meet any of the following:
•	Close contacts of confirmed cases - they include household members, those who shared meals with you or attended a close family gathering with you, those who were with you in an enclosed room for 30 minutes or more and those who are working in close proximity or sharing work space with you.
•	Those who have a travel history to affected countries in the last 14 days and have developed fever and/or respiratory symptoms.
S13_Notes:
First case reported in Brunei: 09 March
/web/20200404205427/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

Contact tracing would have been done by a team from the Ministry of Health (MOH) to identify close contacts of the confirmed cases.  This is to determine if the nature of contact poses risk of virus transmission.  If you have been identified as a close contact of the confirmed case, you will be advised on the measures that you should take i.e. in this case you will be asked to go for testing and will have to undergo self-isolation (under quarantine order).

 
Close contacts are defined as: (i) anyone who has had close contact with a confirmed case within about 1 metre distance for at least 30 minutes in an enclosed area or; (ii) anyone who has stayed at the same place (e.g. household, office space, social gathering) as a confirmed case. The health status of all close contacts will be monitored closely for 14 days from their last exposure to the patient.

S1_Notes:
On March 10th, Brunei’s Ministry of Education announced that the first school term break scheduled for March 16 would be moved up to March 11. 
/web/20200404181841/http://www.moe.gov.bn/SitePages/NewsArticle.aspx?AID=636

On March 25, the Minister announced classes would be held online, effective since March 30
Official statements at: /web/20200405011037/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
S2_Notes:
There are no direct measures for workplace closure, but some procedure and advice have been established by the Ministry of Health (protocol for when a worker is positive for covid-19 and protocol for disinfection of workplace) 
/web/20200404200230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Procedures%20for%20Workplace%20in%20the%20event%20of%20a%20member%20of%20staff%20is%20diagnosed%20with%20COVID-19.pdf
/web/20200404200352/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/Guideline%20for%20Cleaning%20and%20Disinfection%20of%20General%20Workplaces%20%28OHD%20Feb%202020%29.pdf
S3_Notes:
13/03 Ministry of Health informs all mass gatherings, including weddings and sports events are temporarily prohibited.
Source with official media statements: /web/20200404202614/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/3/
From March 17, mosques, suraus and religious halls must be closed (first for a week, then extended for another week on March 23 and for another one on March 30)
From March 18, all cinemas and museums are closed
From March 19, all restaurants are not allowed to have dine-in services; only takeouts
S4_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has provided advisory for safe use of public facilities, such as public transportation, but other tan recommendations there is no measure closing it.
/web/20200404195342/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/ADVISORY%20FOR%20SAFE%20USE%20OF%20PUBLIC%20FACILITIES.pdf
S5_Notes:
The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.
Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx
According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
S6_Notes:
There is no direct policy regarding restrictions to internal movement. Only since March 19 the Ministry of Health released an andvisory for safe use of public facilities in general (supply-sided)
/web/20200404204950/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/guidelines/ADVISORY%20FOR%20SAFE%20USE%20OF%20PUBLIC%20FACILITIES.pdf
S7_Notes:
30/01 Travellers coming from Hubei province are banned entry. Any national that has been in China in the last 14 days must self quarantine for 14 days.

S4_Notes:
All Transport Operators
1. Continuous disinfection of seats, door handles and surfaces on public transport, commercial, and freight vehicles
2. Keeping of windows open for air circulation in public service vehicles.
3. Public transport operators encouraged to use sanitizer dispensers or water and soap at the doors of public service vehicles.
4. Prohibition of hawkers in public service vehicles.
5. Public transport operators must have clinical waste containers for disposal of used tissues.

AIR SERVICES

1. Airlines have been issued with instructions not to board passengers from high risk countries identified by the Director of Public Health.
BOTSWANA RAILWAYS
1. The overnight passenger service and services to Bulawayo Zimbabwe have been suspended.
2. Cross border freight services continue with precautionary measures taken.
• Human to human contact at the exchange stations (Mafikeng & Plumtree) has been reduced/ eliminated. Operations restricted to disconnecting wagons.
• Drivers are starting being provided with packed lunches, gloves and sourcing masks.
PASSENGERS
1. Passengers encouraged to buy their own masks and sanitizers or soap solutions.
2. Passengers encouraged to reduce unnecessary trips both locally and internationally.
3. Passengers are advised to stop handshaking and use other non-contact methods of greeting.
4. Passengers are reminded to avoid touching their faces and always sneeze into a tissue and use elbow if tissue is unavailable. The tissue should be thrown in waste containers
5. Passengers encouraged to bring money that does not need change in paying fares
Temporary suspension of some services
a) All driver Tests (theory and practical).
There is an influx of customers, mostly from the Tertiary institutions, who come for driver test bookings.
b) Applications for passenger permits.
c) Renewal of Drivers licenses. The department will waive penalties for the period beginning 25th March 2020 till the end of suspension.
d) Transport Advisory Board (TAB) and Appeals Tribunal sittings.
e) Conversion of foreign driver’s licensehttps://www.facebook.com/pg/BotswanaGovernment/posts/?ref=page_internal
S7_Notes:
March 24th The Government of Botswana has banned entry of all individuals (except Batswana and Botswana residents) from entering Botswana.
https://web.archive.org/web/20200402143937/https://www.voanews.com/science-health/coronavirus-outbreak/botswana-no-covid-19-cases-closes-borders-after-death-zimbabwe
https://web.archive.org/save/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ 
https://web.archive.org/web/20200402144119/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/326206/botswana-authorities-close-all-borders-on-march-24

S1_Notes: President Masisi announced school closures on 19/3/2020 to begin the next day, the 20/3/2020. https://www.facebook.com/BotswanaGovernment/posts/2832225860193387
S3_Notes:
Total suspension of public gatherings of more than 100 people
https://web.archive.org/web/20200328130238/https://www.gov.bw/sites/default/files/2020-03/Covid19.pdf
S4_Notes:
All Transport Operators
1. Continuous disinfection of seats, door handles and surfaces on public transport, commercial, and freight vehicles
2. Keeping of windows open for air circulation in public service vehicles.
3. Public transport operators encouraged to use sanitizer dispensers or water and soap at the doors of public service vehicles.
4. Prohibition of hawkers in public service vehicles.
5. Public transport operators must have clinical waste containers for disposal of used tissues.

AIR SERVICES

1. Airlines have been issued with instructions not to board passengers from high risk countries identified by the Director of Public Health.
BOTSWANA RAILWAYS
1. The overnight passenger service and services to Bulawayo Zimbabwe have been suspended.
2. Cross border freight services continue with precautionary measures taken.
• Human to human contact at the exchange stations (Mafikeng & Plumtree) has been reduced/ eliminated. Operations restricted to disconnecting wagons.
• Drivers are starting being provided with packed lunches, gloves and sourcing masks.
PASSENGERS
1. Passengers encouraged to buy their own masks and sanitizers or soap solutions.
2. Passengers encouraged to reduce unnecessary trips both locally and internationally.
3. Passengers are advised to stop handshaking and use other non-contact methods of greeting.
4. Passengers are reminded to avoid touching their faces and always sneeze into a tissue and use elbow if tissue is unavailable. The tissue should be thrown in waste containers
5. Passengers encouraged to bring money that does not need change in paying fares
Temporary suspension of some services
a) All driver Tests (theory and practical).
There is an influx of customers, mostly from the Tertiary institutions, who come for driver test bookings.
b) Applications for passenger permits.
c) Renewal of Drivers licenses. The department will waive penalties for the period beginning 25th March 2020 till the end of suspension.
d) Transport Advisory Board (TAB) and Appeals Tribunal sittings.
e) Conversion of foreign driver’s licensehttps://www.facebook.com/pg/BotswanaGovernment/posts/?ref=page_internal

S1_Notes:
9 of 13 provinces & territories across Canada close schools on March 16th:
-Ontario (announced March 12, effective March 16): https://globalnews.ca/news/6668240/coronavirus-ontario-schools-closed/
-Quebec (announced March 13, effective March 16): https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/covid-19-quebec-to-close-all-daycares-schools-cegeps-and-universities-for-at-least-two-weeks-1.4851790
-Alberta (announced March 15, effective March 16): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/covid-coronavirus-update-hinshaw-alberta-edmonton-1.5498467
-Prince Edward Island (announced March 15, effective March 16): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/pei-covid-19-sunday-evening-press-briefing-1.5498653
-New Brunswick (announced March 13, effective March 16): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/covid-19-new-brunswick-coronavirus-1.5496547
-Nova Scotia (announced Marc 15, effective March 16): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/nova-scotia-presumptive-cases-covid-19-coronavirus-1.5498463  
-Manitoba (announced March 13, effective March 16): https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/manitoba-is-closing-all-of-its-schools-due-to-covid-19-1.4852176 
-Newfoundland (announced March 16, effective March 16 – school were open March 18/19 only for students to go pick up their things at scheduled staggered times): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/covid-19-march-16-nl-schools-1.5498831 
-North West Territories (no provincial nor federal government have the authority to close NWT schools - it’s the school districts that do. The NWT government therefore highly recommended that schools be closed as of March 16): https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nwt-schools-closed-until-after-easter-1.5499170
 
It’s important to note that most of the provinces and territories were already planning on being closed the week of March 16 for their regular, one-week “March break”. These regions announced that school closure would extend past March break for multiple weeks (in many cases for two-three weeks after).

S1_Notes:
All public schools across Canada remain closed. 

On March 31st, Ontario government announces that school closure will extend at least until May 1st for teachers and May 4th for students: https://news.ontario.ca/opo/en/2020/03/ontario-extends-school-and-child-care-closures-to-fight-spread-of-covid-19.html 
https://globalnews.ca/news/6755700/coronavirus-ford-government-e-learning-covid-19/

On March 31st, Manitoba government announces that school closure will extend indefinitely: https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/pallister-education-minister-covid-19-measures-1.5516053

On March 31st, Nunavut government announces that school closure will extend until April 20th: https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/nunavut-schools-daycares-closed-covid19-1.5516822

Additional comments on all schools: https://www.cbc.ca/player/play/1718857283912
S2_Notes: North West Territories variety of business types forced to close: https://www.hss.gov.nt.ca/en/services/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/information-employers-and-businesses
S3_Notes: March 31st: Ever province and territory across Canada has public gathering size restrictions at this stage, with some territories (Northwest Territories and Yukon) completely banning public events: https://www.retailcouncil.org/coronavirus-info-for-retailers/provincial-covid-19-resources-and-updates/#yukon
S4_Notes:
March 31st: 
All public transport remains open across Canada, albeit frequency of transit has diminished (e.g. Via rail: https://www.viarail.ca/en/plan-your-trip/customize-your-train-schedule)
https://www.tc.gc.ca/en/initiatives/covid-19-measures-updates-guidance-tc.html
https://cutaactu.ca/en/content/covid-19-resources
https://www.ontario.ca/page/list-essential-workplaces#section-5

CHF 10 BILLION FOR SWISS BUSINESSES HIT BY CORONAVIRUS
ANA MARIA MONTERO @AMMONTEROCNN | 13 March 2020
The Swiss government announced CHF 10 billion in aid for businesses and tightened borders as the number of confirmed coronavirus cases continues to surge. The package looks large but lacks a “radical innovation,” such as a COVID-19 government bond, said Marie Owens Thomsen, global head of research at Indosuez Wealth Management.

S10_Notes: On March 13 President Piñera said that they would create a fund of 220 000 million pesos to finance the purchase of necessary supplies and equipment, the strengthening of the operation of hospitals and diagnostic laboratories, the extension of office hours, the provision of additional beds, the hospitals of accelerated construction, Armed Forces hospitals and other needs.

'China has a policy of meticulous case and contact identification for COVID-19. For example,
in Wuhan more than 1800 teams of epidemiologists, with a minimum of 5 people/team, are
tracing tens of thousands of contacts a day... As of 17 February, in Shenzhen City, among 2842 identified close contacts, 2842 (100%) were traced and 2240 (72%) have completed medical observation. Among
the close contacts, 88 (2.8%) were found to be infected with COVID-19.' https://web.archive.org/web/20200228142208/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/who-china-joint-mission-on-covid-19-final-report.pdf

'Wuhan, the central Chinese city once at the epicenter of the COVID-19 outbreak, has reopened more bus routes on March 29, as the city gets its public transportation system back on track.

The city with a population of some 11 million has added 36 bus routes in the downtown area, bringing the total number to 180, while other districts are allowed to resume bus routes gradually starting from March 29, according to the local transport authority.' https://web.archive.org/web/20200407060749/http://english.www.gov.cn/news/topnews/202003/29/content_WS5e803509c6d0c201c2cbfbb8.html

S2_Notes:
Hubei province: Yang Yunyan, vice-governor of Hubei province states that cinemas, chess rooms, games halls, internet cafes, disco rooms, pubs, KTVs, indoor swimming pools, and likewise indoor entertainment venues remain closed until further notice. ** note: I found the info from 19 April but it's very likely that workplace like these are closed before this date. So it's worth checking what's listed above in this column.

S1_Notes: Schools, universities, private, and higher education institutes closed for four weeks from March 19th: https://web.archive.org/web/20200323010316/https://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/scienceandhealth/Africa-coronavirus-cases-to-rise-as-some-undetected/3073694-5498212-o7o1n3z/index.html ; http://web.archive.org/web/20200323151225/https://afrique.lalibre.be/47921/rdc-le-gouvernement-arrete-des-mesures-contre-le-coronavirus/
S2_Notes: In Kinshasa: Discos, bars, cafes, terraces, and restaurants clsoed until further notice; fewer numbers of itinerant traders reported as well. http://web.archive.org/web/20200323151225/https://afrique.lalibre.be/47921/rdc-le-gouvernement-arrete-des-mesures-contre-le-coronavirus/ ; http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.afrik.com/coronavirus-en-rdc-temoignage-d-un-etudiant-depuis-kinshasa
S3_Notes: In Kinshasa from March 19th, all gathereings, meetings, and celebrations of more than 20 people in public prohibited; sporting activitiees suspended until further notice; mourning in halls and homes banned - instead, immediate burial with limited number of people; church services halted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200323151225/https://afrique.lalibre.be/47921/rdc-le-gouvernement-arrete-des-mesures-contre-le-coronavirus/

S7_Notes: From March 20th until further notice, the suspension of all flights from countries at risk and from transit countries. Only planes and cargo ships and other means of freight transport will be authorized to enter the national territory and their personnel subject to control; Travel to the Democratic Republic of the Congo of all passengers residing in countries at risk postponed until further notice. Border with Angola closed as of March 20th http://web.archive.org/web/20200323151225/https://afrique.lalibre.be/47921/rdc-le-gouvernement-arrete-des-mesures-contre-le-coronavirus/ ;  https://web.archive.org/web/20200323011519/https://actualite.cd/2020/03/21/coronavirus-la-rdc-passe-23-cas-dont-un-premier-deces-dr-eteni-longondo ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200323012037/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/uganda-borders-closed-to-keep-coronavirus-out/1774609; https://web.archive.org/web/20200323141934/https://www.ethiopianairlines.com/aa/en/breaking-news/updates-and-health-advisory-on-the-covid-19-virus

S2_Notes: Kinshasa is ordered into complete lockdown for three weeks taking effect March 28th then following an interval pattern of complete lockdown with two days of movement allowed. However, complete ban suspended at the last minute in response to price hikes in Kinshasa. https://web.archive.org/web/20200330145925/http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2020-03/27/content_75866594.htm https://web.archive.org/web/20200329142536/https://www.africanews.com/2020/03/28/price-hike-forces-dr-congo-to-suspend-kinshasa-lockdown//https://web.archive.org/web/20200330164141/https://newsghana.com.gh/dr-congo-capital-issues-stay-at-home-order-amid-coronavirus-outbreak/

S7_Notes: 'The Congolese government has already taken steps to stop the spread of the virus, including restricting all forms of internal and international travel except for cargo; banning large gatherings; closing bars, restaurants, places of worship and schools; and shutting down borders.' S6_Notes:
The government of Kinshasa has ordered that the Gombe neighborhood of Kinshasa be under a 14-day confinement from April 6 to April 20 to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The government also ordered that Goma be under a 14-day confinement period starting Monday April 6 to prevent the spread of COVID-19. 
https://web.archive.org/web/20200417001004/https://cd.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-kinshasa-democratic-republic-of-the-congo-10/

S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19, here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines for the detection and management of COVID cases that all health providers must follow (issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020) did not include any protocols about contact tracing.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf

S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19, here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines for the detection and management of COVID cases that all health providers must follow (issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020) did not include any protocols about contact tracing.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf

S5_Notes:
Centralised and regular communication and media releases regarding Covid-19 from the Colombian Ministry of Health. 
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx#InplviewHashd16a247c-c76e-40cd-91ca-59390c44b2e9=Paged%3DTRUE-p_SortBehavior%3D0-p_ArticleStartDate%3D20200229%252005%253a00%253a00-p_ID%3D618-PageFirstRow%3D26
S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who 'fits' the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes: On March 6, the National Health Institute issued a new veresion of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions: https://www.famisanar.com.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Anexo_-Instructivo-Vigilancia-COVID-19-v6-06032020.pdf

Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes: On March 6, the National Health Institute issued a new veresion of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions: https://www.famisanar.com.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Anexo_-Instructivo-Vigilancia-COVID-19-v6-06032020.pdf

S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. S2_Notes:
Since February 24, the Labour Ministry identified three kind of workers with risk of exposition to the COVID-19. For that reason, the Ministry gave some general guidelines that employers and
 employees should follow to prevention contagion (see Circular 017 - 2020) http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=90795. Later, on March 10, the Labour Ministry promoted public and private entities to: i) authorize virtual job; ii) adopt
 flexible schedules; and, iii) diminish as most as possible the number of face-to-face meetings (see with the Circular 018 -2020). http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=91129

See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who 'fits' the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes: On March 6, the National Health Institute issued a new veresion of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions: https://www.famisanar.com.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Anexo_-Instructivo-Vigilancia-COVID-19-v6-06032020.pdf

S2_Notes:
Since February 24, the Labour Ministry identified three kind of workers with risk of exposition to the COVID-19. For that reason, the Ministry gave some general guidelines that employers and
 employees should follow to prevention contagion (see Circular 017 - 2020) http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=90795. Later, on March 10, the Labour Ministry promoted public and private entities to: i) authorize virtual job; ii) adopt
 flexible schedules; and, iii) diminish as most as possible the number of face-to-face meetings (see with the Circular 018 -2020). http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=91129
S5_Notes:

The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes: On March 6, the National Health Institute issued a new veresion of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions: https://www.famisanar.com.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Anexo_-Instructivo-Vigilancia-COVID-19-v6-06032020.pdf

S2_Notes:
Since February 24, the Labour Ministry identified three kind of workers with risk of exposition to the COVID-19. For that reason, the Ministry gave some general guidelines that employers and
 employees should follow to prevention contagion (see Circular 017 - 2020) http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=90795. Later, on March 10, the Labour Ministry promoted public and private entities to: i) authorize virtual job; ii) adopt
 flexible schedules; and, iii) diminish as most as possible the number of face-to-face meetings (see with the Circular 018 -2020). http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=91129

S1_Notes:
1. Schools: Since Monday March 16, public schools in the national territory are close and face-to-face classes are not permitted. The changes in the school calendar are available in Circular No. 20 - 2020. http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/34.pdf
2. Universities: Since the national government decreed the national lockdown (enforced since March 25), all universities (public and private) are closed.

See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who 'fits' the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes:
On March 20, the National Health Institute issued a new version of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions:
https://www.studocu.com/co/document/universidad-nacional-de-colombia/salud-publica/otros/anexo-instructivo-vigilancia-covid-v7-2003-2020/7539200/view

S1_Notes:
1. Schools: Since Monday March 16, public schools in the national territory are close and face-to-face classes are not permitted. The changes in the school calendar are available in Circular No. 20 - 2020. http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/34.pdf
2. Universities: Since the national government decreed the national lockdown (enforced since March 25), all universities (public and private) are closed.
S2_Notes:
Since February 24, the Labour Ministry identified three kind of workers with risk of exposition to the COVID-19. For that reason, the Ministry gave some general guidelines that employers and
 employees should follow to prevention contagion (see Circular 017 - 2020) http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=90795. Later, on March 10, the Labour Ministry promoted public and private entities to: i) authorize virtual job; ii) adopt
 flexible schedules; and, iii) diminish as most as possible the number of face-to-face meetings (see with the Circular 018 -2020). http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=91129
S3_Notes:
On March 17, the Health and Social Protection Ministry suspended
 the events of more than 50 individuals in close and open spaces. https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Normatividad_Nuevo/Resolución%20No.%200450%20de%202020.pdf
S5_Notes:
Centralised and regular communication and media releases regarding Covid-19 from the Colombian Ministry of Health. 
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx#InplviewHashd16a247c-c76e-40cd-91ca-59390c44b2e9=Paged%3DTRUE-p_SortBehavior%3D0-p_ArticleStartDate%3D20200229%252005%253a00%253a00-p_ID%3D618-PageFirstRow%3D26
S9_Notes: Banco de la Republica increases the liquidity auction quotas from $17 trillion to $20 trillion. https://www.banrep.gov.co/es/banco-republica-amplia-el-cupo-repos-con-titulos-deuda-privada

S7_Notes: Since March 23 and for 30 days, the Transportation Ministry suspended the “disembarkation, for entry or connection purposes, in the Colombian territory of passengers coming from abroad by air” (see Decree 439 of 2020). https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Gobierno-Nacional-expide-Decreto-439-mediante-cual-suspende-por-30-dias-desembarque-con-fines-ingreso-conexion-pais-200321.aspx
S8_Notes:
Government of Colombia creates the National Emergency Mitigation Fund of almost 1.5 billion USD (6 trillion Colombian Pesos). The government has adopted a series of measures to increase the investment in health care which have focused on redirecting funds that were previously planned for other ends. The national government also created a new fund called “Emergency Mitigation Fund” (FOME) destined to guarantee resources to finance the extraordinary health and economic measures associated with COVID. It is not clear how much is directed to specifically health care.
https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2020/03/gobierno-de-colombia-creo-fondo-de-mitigacion-de-emergencias
https://www.laopinion.com.co/colombia/coronavirus-con-recursos-de-pensiones-y-territorios-crean-fondo-de-mitigacion-193999
S9_Notes: COP 10 trillion program to purchase securities issued by credit institutions, and COP 2 trillion in TES purchases. https://www.banrep.gov.co/es/banco-republica-inyecta-liquidez-permanente-economia-realizando-compras-titulos-deuda-publica-y

https://www.ins.gov.co/Noticias/Coronavirus/Anexo_%20Instructivo%20Vigilancia%20COVID%20v8%2026032020.pdf

S1_Notes:
The Ministry of Education issued Directive No. 4 on March 22, 2020, which instructed Higher Education Institutions (e.g. universities) to operate through e-learning platforms until May 30, 2020.
https://www.mineducacion.gov.co/1759/articles-394296_recurso_1.pdf
S2_Notes:
Since February 24, the Labour Ministry identified three kind of workers with risk of exposition to the COVID-19. For that reason, the Ministry gave some general guidelines that employers and
 employees should follow to prevention contagion (see Circular 017 - 2020) http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=90795. Later, on March 10, the Labour Ministry promoted public and private entities to: i) authorize virtual job; ii) adopt
 flexible schedules; and, iii) diminish as most as possible the number of face-to-face meetings (see with the Circular 018 -2020). http://www.bogotajuridica.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=91129
S3_Notes:
On March 17, the Health and Social Protection Ministry suspended
 the events of more than 50 individuals in close and open spaces. https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Normatividad_Nuevo/Resolución%20No.%200450%20de%202020.pdf
S5_Notes:
Centralised and regular communication and media releases regarding Covid-19 from the Colombian Ministry of Health. 
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx#InplviewHashd16a247c-c76e-40cd-91ca-59390c44b2e9=Paged%3DTRUE-p_SortBehavior%3D0-p_ArticleStartDate%3D20200229%252005%253a00%253a00-p_ID%3D618-PageFirstRow%3D26
S7_Notes: Since March 23 and for 30 days, the Transportation Ministry suspended the “disembarkation, for entry or connection purposes, in the Colombian territory of passengers coming from abroad by air” (see Decree 439 of 2020). https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Gobierno-Nacional-expide-Decreto-439-mediante-cual-suspende-por-30-dias-desembarque-con-fines-ingreso-conexion-pais-200321.aspx
S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who 'fits' the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes:
On March 20, the National Health Institute issued the seventh version of the instructions to manage COVID cases but it did not include specific instructions regarding contact tracing. Here’s the file of the instructions:
https://www.studocu.com/co/document/universidad-nacional-de-colombia/salud-publica/otros/anexo-instructivo-vigilancia-covid-v7-2003-2020/7539200/view
Only on the eighth version of the instructions, the National Health Institute included instructions to chacaterise any close contacts of confirmed COVID cases. The last version of the instructions was issued on March 26, here’s the link to the document:
https://www.ins.gov.co/Noticias/Coronavirus/Anexo_%20Instructivo%20Vigilancia%20COVID%20v8%2026032020.pdf

S3_Notes:
On March 17, the Health and Social Protection Ministry suspended
 the events of more than 50 individuals in close and open spaces. https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Normatividad_Nuevo/Resolución%20No.%200450%20de%202020.pdf
S4_Notes: On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13 (see Decree 457 -2020). Despite of the preventive isolation measures, some exceptions were made, and public transportation is still operating within cities on a restricted basis. However, the public transportation between cities is closed. http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
S5_Notes:
Centralised and regular communication and media releases regarding Covid-19 from the Colombian Ministry of Health.

S6_Notes:
On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13; some exceptions were made for specific types of public servants and employees (e.g. health) (see Decree 457 -2020). http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
Domestic air and terrestrial transportation was also banned during this time. The decree allows mobility for public health purposes.

On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13; some exceptions were made for specific types of public servants and employees (e.g. health) (see Decree 457 -2020). http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
Domestic air and terrestrial transportation was also banned during this time. The decree allows mobility for public health purposes.
S7_Notes: Since March 23 and for 30 days, the Transportation Ministry suspended the “disembarkation, for entry or connection purposes, in the Colombian territory of passengers coming from abroad by air” (see Decree 439 of 2020). https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Gobierno-Nacional-expide-Decreto-439-mediante-cual-suspende-por-30-dias-desembarque-con-fines-ingreso-conexion-pais-200321.aspx
S9_Notes:
NOTES: The decisions taken by the Central Colombian Bank are available here: https://www.banrep.gov.co/es/medidas-banrep-covid-19 
March 30. “The Board of Directors unanimously decided to reduce Banco de la República's benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, placing it at 3.75%”
April 06. All Non Delivery Forward (NDF), which are due before May 01 2020, will be renewed. 
April 08. “all NDFs with maturities before 1 May 2020 will be renewed”
S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S12_Notes:
The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who 'fits' the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.
Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf 
The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:
https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
S13_Notes:
The National Health Institute issued instructions to chacaterise close contacts of confirmed COVID cases. The last version of the instructions was issued on March 26, here’s the link to the document:
https://www.ins.gov.co/Noticias/Coronavirus/Anexo_%20Instructivo%20Vigilancia%20COVID%20v8%2026032020.pdf

S8_Notes:
Summary: The government added 7 billion USD dollars (USD $7,429,659,624.62) to its annual budget to fund economic expenditures required to deal with COVID.
April 4. Decree 518. Delivery of non conditional monetary transfers- Solidarity Income Programme. Through this programme, the government is trying to provide an additional income for people and homes in situation of poverty and vulnerability, which are not beneficiary of other social programmes of the government ( Familias en Acción, Protección Social al Adulto Mayor - Colombia Mayor, Jóvenes en Acción or tax compensation). Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/190_decreto_518_2020.pdf 

April 5. Decree 519. 
Article 1. Addition to the income and capital resources budget: QUINCE BILLONES CIEN MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($15.100.000.000.000) [$3,714,829,812.31 USD]
Article 2.  Addition to the spending budget or the appropriation law: QUINCE BILLONES CIEN MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($15.100.000.000.000) [3,714,829,812.31 USD]
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/191_decreto_519_2020.pdf 
April 6. Decree 522. 
Article 1. Addition to the income and capital resources budget: TRES BILLONES DOSCIENTOS CINCUENTA MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($3,250,000,000,000) [799549462.915813 USD]
Article 2. Addition to the spending budget or the appropriation law: TRES BILLONES DOSCIENTOS CINCUENTA MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($3,250,000,000,000) [799549462.915813 USD]
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/193_decreto522_2020.pdf 
April 6. Decree 520.

https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx#InplviewHashd16a247c-c76e-40cd-91ca-59390c44b2e9=Paged%3DTRUE-p_SortBehavior%3D0-p_ArticleStartDate%3D20200229%252005%253a00%253a00-p_ID%3D618-PageFirstRow%3D26
S6_Notes:
On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13; some exceptions were made for specific types of public servants and employees (e.g. health) (see Decree 457 -2020). http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
Domestic air and terrestrial transportation was also banned during this time. The decree allows mobility for public health purposes.
S7_Notes: Since March 23 and for 30 days, the Transportation Ministry suspended the “disembarkation, for entry or connection purposes, in the Colombian territory of passengers coming from abroad by air” (see Decree 439 of 2020). https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Gobierno-Nacional-expide-Decreto-439-mediante-cual-suspende-por-30-dias-desembarque-con-fines-ingreso-conexion-pais-200321.aspx
S8_Notes:
Summary: The government added 7 billion USD dollars (USD $7,429,659,624.62) to its annual budget to fund economic expenditures required to deal with COVID.
April 4. Decree 518. Delivery of non conditional monetary transfers- Solidarity Income Programme. Through this programme, the government is trying to provide an additional income for people and homes in situation of poverty and vulnerability, which are not beneficiary of other social programmes of the government ( Familias en Acción, Protección Social al Adulto Mayor - Colombia Mayor, Jóvenes en Acción or tax compensation). Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/190_decreto_518_2020.pdf 

April 5. Decree 519. 
Article 1. Addition to the income and capital resources budget: QUINCE BILLONES CIEN MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($15.100.000.000.000) [$3,714,829,812.31 USD]
Article 2.  Addition to the spending budget or the appropriation law: QUINCE BILLONES CIEN MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($15.100.000.000.000) [3,714,829,812.31 USD]
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/191_decreto_519_2020.pdf 
April 6. Decree 522. 
Article 1. Addition to the income and capital resources budget: TRES BILLONES DOSCIENTOS CINCUENTA MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($3,250,000,000,000) [799549462.915813 USD]
Article 2. Addition to the spending budget or the appropriation law: TRES BILLONES DOSCIENTOS CINCUENTA MIL MILLONES OF COLOMBIAN PESOS ($3,250,000,000,000) [799549462.915813 USD]
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/193_decreto522_2020.pdf 
April 6. Decree 520. 
Article 1. Modification of the schedule for the payment of public taxes. 
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/192_decreto_520_2020.pdf 
April 8. Decree 530. Transitory exemption of the Tax on Financial Transactions. The total amount is of cuts is not mentioned or calculated.  
Decree: http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/197_DECRETO_530_2020.pdf
S9_Notes:
NOTES: The decisions taken by the Central Colombian Bank are available here: https://www.banrep.gov.co/es/medidas-banrep-covid-19 
March 30. “The Board of Directors unanimously decided to reduce Banco de la República's benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, placing it at 3.75%”
April 06. All Non Delivery Forward (NDF), which are due before May 01 2020, will be renewed. 
April 08. “all NDFs with maturities before 1 May 2020 will be renewed”
S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S11_Notes: Public investment in vaccines has not been  announced or undertaken by the government.
S12_Notes: The previous testing policy has not changed. Only individuals with COVID-19 symptoms are being tested.
S13_Notes: The contact tracing policy has not changed.

S1_Notes:
The Ministry of Education issued Directive No. 4 on March 22, 2020, which instructed Higher Education Institutions (e.g. universities) to operate through e-learning platforms until May 30, 2020.
https://www.mineducacion.gov.co/1759/articles-394296_recurso_1.pdf
S2_Notes:
The decree that ordered the mandatory preventive isolation (from March 25 - 13 April), established certain exceptions for employees that are allowed to leave their homes.
 http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
S3_Notes:
The cancelation of public events remains unchanged. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S4_Notes: On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13 (see Decree 457 -2020). Despite of the preventive isolation measures, some exceptions were made, and public transportation is still operating within cities on a restricted basis. However, the public transportation between cities is closed. http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf

S1_Notes:
The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by  the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S2_Notes:
The workplace closing remains mostly unchanged, except for one additional exception related to public works. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S3_Notes:
The cancelation of public events remains unchanged. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S4_Notes:
The limited operation of public transport remains unchanged. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020. The Decree 531 establishes that public transport must be guaranteed for those activities that are necessary to deal with COVID-19 and the economic activities that are allowed by the decree (e.g. food, banking etc.).
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf

Domestic air and terrestrial transportation was also banned during this time. The decree allows mobility for public health purposes.
S7_Notes:

https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx#InplviewHashd16a247c-c76e-40cd-91ca-59390c44b2e9=Paged%3DTRUE-p_SortBehavior%3D0-p_ArticleStartDate%3D20200229%252005%253a00%253a00-p_ID%3D618-PageFirstRow%3D26
S6_Notes:
On March 22, the Ministry of Interior ordered the preventive isolation of all inhabitants of Colombia from March 25 to April 13; some exceptions were made for specific types of public servants and employees (e.g. health) (see Decree 457 -2020). http://www.regiones.gov.co/Inicio/assets/files/82-decreto-457.pdf
Domestic air and terrestrial transportation was also banned during this time. The decree allows mobility for public health purposes.
S7_Notes:
The strict control of international travel remain unchanged, the decree that extended the general lock-down and quarantine until April 27 did not lift the prohibition of international passenger flights. Here’s the link to Decree 531:
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S9_Notes:
NOTES: The decisions taken by the Central Colombian Bank are available here: https://www.banrep.gov.co/es/medidas-banrep-covid-19 
March 30. “The Board of Directors unanimously decided to reduce Banco de la República's benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, placing it at 3.75%”
April 06. All Non Delivery Forward (NDF), which are due before May 01 2020, will be renewed. 
April 08. “all NDFs with maturities before 1 May 2020 will be renewed”
S10_Notes: On March 22, the Colombian government announced that 6 billion colombian pesos (USD $1,457,386,095.62) would be spent in health to address COVID. However, the expenditures have not been officially incorporated to the budget. See the press release here: https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/Presidente-Duque-anuncia-sector-salud-recibira-mas-de-6-billones-de-pesos-fechas-entregas-recursos-para-colombianos-200322.aspx
S11_Notes: Public investment in vaccines has not been  announced or undertaken by the government.
S12_Notes: The previous testing policy has not changed. Only individuals with COVID-19 symptoms are being tested.
S13_Notes: The contact tracing policy has not changed.

S1_Notes:
The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by  the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S2_Notes:
The workplace closing remains mostly unchanged, except for one additional exception related to public works. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S3_Notes:
The cancelation of public events remains unchanged. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020.
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S4_Notes:
The limited operation of public transport remains unchanged. The general lock-down and quarantine was prolonged until April 27 by the Decree 531 issued by the President on April 08, 2020. The Decree 531 establishes that public transport must be guaranteed for those activities that are necessary to deal with COVID-19 and the economic activities that are allowed by the decree (e.g. food, banking etc.).
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf

The government has continued its educative and informative campaigns about COVID-19. Additionally, the Decree 516, issued on April 4 by the Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies, established that during the “State of National Emergency”  (that finalizes, unless it is extended, on April 15) open television channels must offer spaces for government messages about COVID-19 at certain periodic schedules. Here’s the link for Decree 516:
https://www.mintic.gov.co/portal/604/articles-126488_dec_516.pdf

https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf
S7_Notes:
The strict control of international travel remain unchanged, the decree that extended the general lock-down and quarantine until April 27 did not lift the prohibition of international passenger flights. Here’s the link to Decree 531:
https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20531%20DEL%208%20DE%20ABRIL%20DE%202020.pdf

S1_Notes:
Cape Verde government announced school closures for all and public schools in the country. Not covered by this measure, according to a government source, are the daycare centers that receive children between 0 and 3 years old, because they “belong to the care network” and, therefore, the decision will be up to the administration of each daycare center.

Source: http://capeverdehub.com/2020/03/19/cape-verde-closes-all-public-schools-amid-covid-19-pandemic/
S3_Notes:
Boa Vista under quarantine

https://www.governo.cv/
S4_Notes:
Local public transport allowed to operate at a reduced level of service.

Source: https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/328671/cape-verde-authorities-declare-nationwide-state-of-emergency-in-place-until-april-17-update-3
S6_Notes: Drafted on Saturday, March 28 but came into force on April 1 and would remain till at least April 17 2020. All citizens have been instructed to remain at home unless they need to carry out essential activities such as buying goods or other essential items, going to work (if unable to work from home), hospitals, or health centres, caring for an individual and walking pets
S7_Notes:
Effective 3/18/2020 all air connections from all European countries including Portugal are prohibited according to information from the Government of Cape Verde. The USA, Brazil and in certain African countries including Senegal and Nigeria.
Source: http://capeverdehub.com/2020/03/18/cape-verde-bans-travel-from-the-usa-and-european-countries-due-to-covid-19-epidemic/
Revised draft on Saturday, March 28 but came into force on April 1 and would remain till at least April 17 2020.  No commercial flights out of Cape Verde and all inter-island flights have been suspended until at least April 17. The Cape Verdean authorities have also closed all sea borders. Exceptions are for cargo flights and flights for foreign citizens wishing to return home.
S8_Notes:
Reported on 27 March 2020.

Bank of Cabo Verde provides €400 million to banks in response to Covid-19. Reduction of the benchmark interest rate by 125 basis points, from 1.5% to 0.25%.

Reduction in the rate of the permanent loan liquidity facility by 250 basis points, from 3% to 0.5%.

Established a credit line for banks, via the Long Term Financing Monetary Operation (OMF), with special conditions, at an interest rate of 0.75%.

Reduction in the permanent liquidity absorption rate by five basis points, from 0.1% to 0.05%.

Source: https://macauhub.com.mo/2020/03/27/pt-banco-de-cabo-verde-disponibiliza-400-milhoes-de-euros-a-banca-em-resposta-ao-covid-19/

Reported on 13-14 April 2020
Of the credit lines of PTE 4 billion made available to companies last week as a way of mitigating and combating the effects of COVID-19 on the Cape Verdean economy, over PTE 1 billion has already been requested by around 500 companies.

Moratorium on interest payments extended to City Councils and all those who have an insurance contract, will have an additional period of 60 days, so that they can proceed with the payment of their commitments.

Enforcing Decree-Law No. 38/2020 on April 1, 2020 (runs until September 30, 2020), to alleviate any difficulties in the normal fulfilment of the payment obligations of debtors in the banking system (https: //www.bcv.cv)
S9_Notes: The World Bank Board of Executive Directors approved today a $5 million credit from the International Development Association (IDA)* to support the Archipelago of Cabo Verde in strengthening its preparedness and response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
S10_Notes:
Since 16 March tests are being made in Cape Verde rather than abroad, by the Laboratório de Virologia de Cabo Verde, in Praia. The Cape Verde Virology Laboratory, which began conducting screening tests for the new coronavirus on Saturday, has the capacity to perform up to 300 daily tests and make the results available within 24 hours, an official source said today. 

Source: https://www.asemana.publ.cv/?Laboratorio-de-Cabo-Verde-com-capacidade-para-300-testes-diarios&ak=1
S12_Notes: Takes 24 hours to receive the outcome of the test although the test can be done in 3 hours. Started in 16 March 2020
